string_table.name: npnxnanbnsnfns00001000011
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: select a term to learn more. abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

action research a process that “brings together action and reflection, as well as theory and practice, in participation with others, in the pursuit of practical solutions to issues of pressing concern” (bradbury, 2015, p. 1). assessment tasks that are done for and with students, rather than to them, to understand what students know and can do, so teachers can plan effectively. assessment capability assessment capability is where teachers demonstrate competence to incorporate and use assessment to effectively promote the learning of all students (charteris & smardon, 2022). a abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz action research assessment capability assessment
b abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

co-teaching collaborative teaching between teachers and teacher aides to enhance explicit teaching. critical components of explicit teaching the framework to explain explicit teaching used in this micro-credential. cognitive load theory coined by john sweller (1988) and built upon the ideas that (a) there is a limit to how much new information the human brain can process at one time and (b) there are no known limits to how much stored information can be processed at one time (cese, 2017). chunking new content is broken down into small, manageable ‘chunks’ or sections of learning. c chunking cognitive load theory co-teaching critical components of explicit teaching abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

data literacy refers to the ability to transform information into actionable instructional knowledge and practices by collecting, analysing and interpreting all types of data (assessment, school climate, behavioural, snapshot, longitudinal, moment-to- moment, etc.) to help determine instructional steps. differentiation planning and implementing strategies that support the progress of all students towards challenging learning goals. diagnostic assessments similar to pre-assessments, in that they are done prior to planning and used to identify areas of strength and weakness. t hey may be standardised and more general in nature. d data literacy diagnostic assessments differentiation abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

exit ticket brief questions or prompts given to students at the end of a lesson to check their understanding of the lesson content. they are aligned to a lesson's learning intentions and success criteria. e exit ticket abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

formative assessment evaluating student learning to provide feedback to students and devise/change teaching and learning programs (aitsl, 2017). can be formal or informal. flexible groups structuring groups based on the context of learning. f flexible groups formative assessment abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

graphic organiser useful tools to scaffold and support students to understand, classify, organise and connect information. examples include venn diagrams, flow charts and tree maps. g graphic organiser abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
h abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i do, we do, you do a teaching model based on the gradual release of responsibility for learning from the teacher to the student. i i do, we do, you do abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
j abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
k abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

long-term memory the memory system where large amounts of information are stored semi-permanently (cese, 2017). learning intentions student-friendly version of the essential content begin taught within a lesson. l abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz learning intentions long-term memory

multi-tiered system of supports (mtss) a framework used to support educators to implement evidence-based instructional practices for all students, including those who may require more targeted or intensive instruction while monitoring the impact of the intervention (aero, 2024). m abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz multi-tiered system of supports (mtss)

noticing is the ‘ability to attend intentionally to classroom events that are important to the processes of teaching and learning’ (michalsky, 2021, p. 2). it allows you to focus on what matters, draw inferences from what you observe and adapt the way you teach. noticing misconceptions about how students learn. neuromyths n noticing neuromyths abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
o abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

professional learning community (plc) collaboration, sharing and ongoing critical interrogation of teaching practices in line with professional standards (aitsl, n.d.). professional learning any activities that teachers engage in that develop their professional knowledge and practice to support student learning (vit, 2024). pre-assessment process of gathering information about your students' knowledge, skills and abilities before beginning to plan for a sequence of lessons. point of need readiness of students to engage with the content being taught (also see 'student readiness'). peer feedback students provide feedback in a supported way to each other. p peer feedback point of need pre-assessment professional learning professional learning community (plc) abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

quality assessment accurately assesses what it is supposed to measure (wiliam et al., 2024). it helps teachers understand student learning in a way that is transparent and clear (suskie, 2018). q abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz quality assessment
r abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

summative assessment these assessments are used to make a 'final' determination of student achievement against a set of criteria. they usually happen at the end of a teaching sequence and may be created by teachers. support staff staff in schools who support teachers. they may be known as teacher aides, school services officers, educational assistants, paraprofessionals or learning support assistants - or you might use a different term. summative feedback evaluating student achievement of pre-determined criteria at a point in time (aitsl, 2017). success criteria student-friendly version of what a successful demonstration of learning looks like in a lesson. should be directly aligned with the lesson's learning intentions. student self-assessment students reflect on their own learning progress to assess their performance against pre-established criteria or goals. student readiness proximity of students to the content that is to be taught (also see 'point of need'). schema organises elements of information according to how they will be used (cese, 2017). scaffold using a range of strategies to support student learning that are gradually removed as students work towards and develop proficiency. s scaffold schema student readiness student self-assessment success criteria summative assessment summative feedback support staff abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
t abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
universal design for learning (udl) a framework to improve and optimise access to teaching and learning for all students (cast, 2024). u abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz universal design for learning (udl)
v abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

working memory the memory system where small amounts of information are stored for a very short duration (cese, 2017). worked example a step-by-step illustration of the process required to complete a task or solve a problem (mit, n.d.). w worked example working memory abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
x abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
y abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
z abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
